title: Peanut Sauce (Sambal Satay)
ingredients: 20 dried chili peppers, soaked, well drained with seeds removed
1 stem of lemongrass, lower part sliced into pieces
1 tablespoon coriander seeds, dry-roasted in a skillet
1 teaspoon caraway seed, dry-roasted in a skillet
The juice from 3 teaspoons of tamarind pulp dissolved in 2 cups of water
instructions: Crush the chili peppers in a mortar with a pestle, adding the lemongrass, ginger, garlic, coriander, and caraway seeds.  Continue working the mixture until it has an even consistency.
Stir in the tamarind pulp into the water then strain through a sieve to remove the pulp from the water.  Reserve the water and discard the pulp.

Heat the oil in a skillet and fry the crushed ingredients, until the aromas develop and the oil separates.  Add the ground peanuts, the strained juice of the tamarind, sugar and salt.  Mix together well and bring to a boil, stirring occasionally.  Reduce the heat and simmer until the sauce is syrupy and the oil rises to the surface.
Remove any free floating oil and serve the sauce.
Remarks:  The sauce is suitable as a dip with barbecue chicken or beef.
Source:  Southeast Asian Specialties:  A Culinary Journey, Culinaria Könemann, © 1998 Könemann Verlagsgesellschaft mbH, Bonner Strasse 126 · D-50968 Cologne.
